TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {100215=Although never officially colonised, Botswana was granted independence from Britain on September 30th, 1966. Diamonds were discovered in the country in 1967, which provided a steady stream of revenue that continues to this day. Unlike many other African nations, Botswana enjoys peace, prosperity and a relatively high standard of living. Equal rights and freedom of speech are granted to all under the constitution, the economy is stable due to the growth of the mining and tourism industries, and literacy rates are improving rapidly., 91907=Winter (April through August) is a good time to visit Botswana. The days are usually mild and wildlife is generally quite easy to spot. The summer can bring frequent rain, which can make it difficult to travel around some of the national parks. Wildlife also tends to disperse during the summer rains, making animals a little harder to spot., 99628=The land of Botswana and surrounding regions have been inhabited by tribal groups for thousands of years, with tribes migrating into the area, from the lands now known as Zambia and Congo, sometime around 200-500 AD. In 1885, the region came under British influence and became known as the Bechuanaland Protectorate, mainly as a tactic to avoid being overrun by the Boers who were campaigning in the region. This status continued for decades, until increasing nationalism in the 1950s led to an internal push for independence.}
textBeforeTable: Recommended reading Further reading 10. Refrain from buying ivory or other products harvested from endangered animals. 9. When on community visits or homestays, refrain from giving gifts or money to locals. 8. Please ask and receive permission before taking photos of people, including children. 7. Refrain from supporting businesses that exploit or abuse endangered animals. 6. Shop for locally made products. Supporting local artisans helps keep traditional crafts alive. 5. Learn some local language and don't be afraid to use it - simple greetings will help break the ice. 4. When bargaining at markets, stay calm, be reasonable and keep a smile on your face. It's meant to be fun! 3. Always dispose of litter thoughtfully, including cigarette butts. 2. For environmental reasons, try to avoid buying bottled water. Fill a reusable water bottle or canteen with filtered water instead. 1. Be considerate of Botswana’s customs, traditions, religion and culture. Top responsible travel tips for Botswana Intrepid is committed to travelling in a way that is respectful of local people, their culture, local economies and the environment. It's important to remember that what may be acceptable behaviour, dress and language in your own country, may not be appropriate in another. Please keep this in mind while travelling.
